Award.AwardTitle: ABR: Models of natural selection, development, and life history
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop evolutionary theories about the characteristics of bacteria and other microbes. Previous work showed the importance of variability in food and other resources over space and time. For example, continuous and predictable resource environments favor microbes that grow slowly and use resources efficiently. By contrast, temporary resource environments favor microbes that compete strongly among themselves, grow rapidly, and use resources inefficiently. Those different patterns of competition and resource use have cascading effects on the surrounding biological communities. In this research, the investigator will test hypotheses about the primary factors that influence key microbial traits. The work requires synthesis of diverse studies from other fields, and the novel theoretical work is expected to create new approaches to fundamental problems in ecology and evolution.

Understanding bacterial characters is important, because our bodies carry trillions of bacteria. Recent research shows that those bacteria influence nearly every aspect of our health. Beyond our bodies, studies of soil, plant growth, and cycling of nutrients through ecosystems also show strong influence by numerous and diverse bacteria and other microbes. To understand those microbial inputs, one must study the ecological and evolutionary processes that have influenced the characteristics of the microbes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed theory to understand how natural processes shape broad patterns in biology. Two examples illustrate the theory and application.

First, the age of death, the age of cancer onset, and the time to failure from disease often follow a characteristic pattern in populations. Similarly, the size of trees in different forests also follows a characteristic "shape" when plotting the number of trees of each size on a graph. This project developed new theory to understand why such characteristic patterns recur in different problems of biology. The theory provides a new way to understand the similarities and differences between many commonly observed patterns that, in the past, had seemed puzzling.

In the second example, this project analyzed the diverse forms of molecules that bacteria produce, secrete, and take up from the environment. Vitamin B12 provides a good example. Most bacteria require vitamin B12 to grow. That vitamin is a complex molecule that is "expensive" to produce, costing much energy and much molecular machinery to build. Some bacteria produce their own B12. Others cannot make the vitamin, and instead take up free B12 molecules from the environment that were secreted by other bacteria. The puzzle is that B12 is made in a variety of molecular forms. Why the variety? The ability to take up B12 of one particular form does not include the ability to take up the other forms. A bacterial population that makes its own rare, private form can pass the molecules between themselves and avoid other bacteria from "pirating" their stock of vitamins. Such competition and variety leads to interesting questions about which bacteria make which forms and which bacteria can take up which forms for their own use.

This project brought together the information and puzzles for B12 variety and also for other bacterial molecules that vary in a similar way. From that synthesis of basic information, this project developed theories about the natural processes that influence variety and competition, and how such theories may be tested in future experiments.

This project also developed theories for other biological problems. In all cases, the unifying themes were the same. Find the essential puzzle from the confusing complexity of nature. Formulate basic theory that provides potential alternative solutions for the puzzle. Consider what sorts of future experiments could tell us which solution is likely to be the correct one.
